I had a similar issue when I tried to specific an absolute path. It seems to be that templateexporter::_load_template has some magic to check whether a .tpl is at the end of the command line option.

On top of making relative/absolute paths working it would be also quite handy to be able to place the templates inside the ipython config directory.

You can put template files wherever you want, but they need to be on TemplateExporter.template_path, which you can customize. Templates cannot be outside any of the template directories ('..' in the template name immediately results in TemplateNotFound in jinja).

 I use this in my config:

``` python
c.TemplateExporter.template_path = ['.', os.path.expanduser("~/dev/ip/notebook-templates")]
```

and then put any custom templates in `~/dev/ip/notebook-templates`, which I can load by name. If you add `/` to your template_path, loading templates by abspath should work, as well. You can add `..` to  template_path, you just can't have a template with `..` in its name.

Hi!  I know this issue is kind of old, but I ran into this (or something closely related) and was able to work around it like this:

```
jupyter nbconvert \
  --NotebookApp.TemplateExporter.template_path=['./scripts', '/opt/conda/lib/python3.5/site-packages/nbconvert/templates/html/'] \
  --to html \
  --template ./scripts/parse-html.tpl \
  main.ipynb
```

My template is in the "scripts" directory off of root.
